manuscript.title: Muraqqaʿāt / مرقعات
manuscript.title_alt: Süleymaniye Murakka Koleksiyonu 13 — Muhammed el-Muhlisî Hamdullah İbnü'ş-Şeyh Murakkaʿı (Kur'ân-ı Kerim Murakkaʿı)
manuscript.calligrapher: Muhammed el-Muhlisî Hamdullah İbnü'ş-Şeyh — attributed from teşpit fişi (identification card); no ketebe inscription found
manuscript.calligrapher_dates: Active period uncertain; no ketebe documented. The 'İbnü'ş-Şeyh' (son of the Şeyh) epithet designates a member of the Şeyh Hamdullah calligraphic lineage. If the attribution is correct, this calligrapher was active during or after the career of Şeyh Hamdullah (AH 840–926 / 1436–1520 CE), in the period when the lineage produced second- and third-generation students.
manuscript.calligrapher_note: ATTRIBUTION CAUTION: The YEK genel_notlar states: 'Ketebe kaydı görülmemektedir. Teşpit fişinde hattat olarak Muhammed el-Muhlisî Hamdullah İbnü'ş-Şeyh ismi yazılmıştır.' This translates: 'No ketebe inscription is seen. On the identification card (teşpit fişi), the name Muhammed el-Muhlisî Hamdullah İbnü'ş-Şeyh is written as the calligrapher.' The attribution thus rests entirely on the teşpit fişi — an administrative identification card, not a primary source — and must be treated as a scholarly attribution, not a documented autograph. The 'İbnü'ş-Şeyh' epithet (Arabic: ابن الشيخ, 'son of the Shaykh') connects this calligrapher to the Şeyh Hamdullah tradition. Şeyh Hamdullah Amasî (AH 840–926 / 1436–1520 CE) is the foundational figure of the Ottoman naskh / nesih tradition: appointed calligraphy master to Sultan Bayezid II, he standardized the Ottoman nesih hand and founded the school that shaped all subsequent Ottoman Quranic calligraphy. 'Muhammed el-Muhlisî' is a further element of the attributed name; 'Muhlisî' (from ihlâs / sincerity) may be a calligraphic epithet or a pen name. The attributed calligrapher cannot be definitively identified in published biographical dictionaries without further specialist research. The attribution is nevertheless significant: if correct, SM 00013 is a direct product of the Şeyh Hamdullah school — among the most important calligraphic lineages in Ottoman history.
manuscript.date_ah: before 1202 AH (terminus ante quem from vakf seal). Probable: 15th–16th century if the Şeyh Hamdullah lineage attribution is correct; alternatively 17th–18th century if the attribution reflects a later follower of the school.
manuscript.date_ce: before 1787–88 CE (terminus ante quem). If İbnü'ş-Şeyh attribution is correct: possibly 15th–16th century (c. 1480–1600, consistent with the Hamdullah school's active period). If a later follower: possibly 17th–18th century.
manuscript.date_note: The vakf seal of Fethizâde Mustafa Efendi dated AH 1202 / 1787–88 CE provides an absolute terminus ante quem shared by all SM albums. The production date is highly uncertain due to the absence of a ketebe inscription. If the teşpit fişi attribution to Hamdullah İbnü'ş-Şeyh is accepted, the album was likely produced in the late 15th or 16th century — within the active period of the Şeyh Hamdullah school. If the attribution reflects a more distant school follower, the album could be as late as the 17th–18th century. The physical dimensions (328×233 mm — the largest album in the SM corpus examined to date), the content (Quranic text), and the quality of the framing system are all consistent with a significant early production date, but cannot be independently confirmed without specialist paleographic analysis. FOLLOW-UP: Specialist calligraphic comparison with documented Hamdullah school manuscripts is urgently needed to verify or revise this attribution.
manuscript.format: Murakkaʿ (مرقعات) — bound calligraphic album of 11 yaprak (leaves), muhtelif satır (various line-counts). Quranic content. Multi-layer compound framing system with distinctive diagonal gold-and-white striped border bands; serlevha (illuminated headpiece) on opening leaf; zerefşân margins; lacquer binding.
manuscript.format_note: A bound Ottoman Quranic murakkaʿ album of 11 yaprak (folios) digitized as 12 IIIF pages. Physical dimensions: 328×233 mm (album) — 275×177 mm (text writing area). These are the largest album dimensions in the SM corpus examined to date. Script: Nesih (نسخ) only — no sülüs component, unlike SM 00006 and SM 00009. Content appears to be consecutive Quranic text: Surat al-Baqara (identified on p003), a mid-Quran surah (p007), and Surat al-Anfāl (identified on p012). Gold verse-separator roundels (durak) throughout. A serlevha (illuminated headpiece) with gold cartouche appears on p012. The calligraphic format — large nesih on ruled leaves with zerefşân margins — is consistent with the Şeyh Hamdullah school of Quranic calligraphy. The album is distinguished by its exceptionally complex framing system featuring diagonal gold-and-white striped border bands, a feature documented in high-quality 16th–17th century Ottoman murakkaʿ production.
manuscript.script: Nesih (نسخ) — formal Quranic naskh. No sülüs component.
manuscript.notes: CORPUS SIGNIFICANCE: SM 00013 is among the most significant albums in the Süleymaniye Murakka Koleksiyonu on three grounds: (1) CALLIGRAPHIC ATTRIBUTION: The teşpit fişi attribution to Muhammed el-Muhlisî Hamdullah İbnü'ş-Şeyh connects this album to the Şeyh Hamdullah school — the foundational tradition of Ottoman Quranic calligraphy. If confirmed by specialist paleographic analysis, this would be a major calligraphic monument. (2) FRAMING SYSTEM: The album displays an exceptionally complex 5-layer compound framing system including the distinctive Ottoman murakkaʿ feature of diagonal gold-and-white striped border bands (alternating gold and white diagonal bands in wide outer border strips) — a feature not previously documented in the SM corpus and visible on all calligraphy pages. (3) SIZE: The album's physical dimensions (328×233 mm) are the largest among the SM albums examined and suggest a high-status commission. The absence of mülevven paper — initially misidentified in triage as 'teal/green mülevven' — is confirmed: the green and salmon elements visible in images are framing bands, not colored paper stock. The margin paper is buff/cream with zerefşân. CRITICAL NOTE ON FALSE POSITIVE: Do not attribute mülevven to this album. The triage error (green from cedvel border bands misread as green mülevven paper) has been corrected based on visual examination of IIIF images. Cross-reference: SM 00014 (sm_00014) shares the same calligrapher attribution (Muhammed el-Muhlisî Hamdullah İbnü'ş-Şeyh from teşpit fişi). Comparative paleographic study of both albums' calligraphy could help evaluate the attribution's reliability.

paper_decoration.summary: SM 00013 presents a richly framed Quranic murakkaʿ without mülevven (colored paper) but with two distinct decorative programs: (1) Zerefşân margins: the outer margin paper (buff/cream ground) carries zerefşân (gold-sprinkled) decoration, confirmed on pp003, 007, and 012 at IIIF resolution. The gold sprinkling is lighter than SM 00006 but clearly present as scattered gold particles on the buff/cream margin zone. Dark speckling is also visible (possibly oxidized silver or deliberate ink spatter). (2) Complex compound framing system: every calligraphic page is enclosed within a 5-layer frame comprising — from outside inward — (a) outer gold ruled frame; (b) buff/cream outer margin with zerefşân; (c) distinctive diagonal gold-and-white striped border bands (alternating gold and white diagonal lines in a wide band); (d) sage-green ruled band; (e) salmon/peach ruled band; (f) inner red line; (g) cream text block. The diagonal striped bands are the most unusual and distinctive decorative feature of this album — a sophisticated Ottoman calligraphic framing device not documented in other SM albums in this corpus. (3) Serlevha (illuminated headpiece) on p012: a gold cartouche with polychrome floral illumination (blue ground / hatāyī-rūmī motifs in classical Ottoman style) marks the opening of a new surah section. The album does NOT contain mülevven (uniformly colored paper stock): the green and salmon colors visible in images are exclusively framing bands within the compound cedvel system, not paper coloring.
paper_decoration.distribution_notes: Zerefşân on outer margin (buff/cream ground): pp003, 007, 012 confirmed. Diagonal gold-and-white striped framing bands: pp003, 007, 012 confirmed; assumed throughout all interior calligraphic pages. Serlevha/illuminated headpiece: p012 confirmed. Pages not sampled (pp002, 004, 005, 006, 008, 009, 010, 011): assumed to continue the framing system; mülevven absence assumed to be consistent throughout based on examined pages. Full examination requires 8 additional pages.

technique_terms.ottoman: zerefşân / yaldız serpme — altın tanecikleri krem/bej zeminde, kenar bölgelerinde; çapraz altın-beyaz şeritli pervaz — murakkaʿ çerçeve sisteminin ayırt edici özelliği; altın cedvel — çok katmanlı bileşik çerçeve sistemi (5 kat: altın dış çerçeve, krem zerefşânlı dış kenar, çapraz şeritli pervaz, adaçayı yeşili bant, somon/toz pembe bant, kırmızı iç çerçeve); serlevha — altın kartuşlu tezhipli başlık; nesih — Osmanlı hat geleneğinde Kur'ân nesih yazısı.
technique_terms.persian: zarafshān / afshān (افشان) — gold-sprinkled outer margin; jadval-e murakkab (جدول مرکب) — compound multi-layer ruling system; sarlawḥ (سرلوح) — illuminated headpiece; naskh (نسخ) — Quranic naskh script.
technique_terms.arabic: dhahab marshūsh (ذهب مرشوش) — gold-sprinkled outer margin; jadwal murakkab (جدول مركب) — compound multi-layer ruling; ʿunwān (عنوان) — illuminated headpiece; naskh (نسخ) — Quranic script.

The complete decoration program — zerefşân margins, 5-layer compound framing with diagonal striped bands, and serlevha — is documented here exclusively from visual examination of IIIF images and the visual-confirmation session of 2026-02-28.

paper.color: Buff/cream (outer margin zones on all examined calligraphic pages — the dominant paper color of this album). Text panels: cream/ivory âharlı (sized and burnished) paper, same hue as margins. No mülevven (colored paper): the green and salmon hues visible in images are exclusively framing bands (cedvel/pervaz elements), not paper coloring. Binding cover: dark brown/maroon leather.
paper.preparation: Text panels on cream âharlı (sized and burnished) paper. Outer margin paper: buff/cream stock with zerefşân (gold particle) sprinkling. The zerefşân is lighter in concentration than SM 00006. Framing bands appear to be ruled in colored pigments (sage-green, salmon, red) rather than applied paper strips.
paper.weight: Indeterminate from IIIF images; the large album format (328×233 mm) suggests heavier paper stock for stability.
paper.decoration: Zerefşân on outer margin (buff/cream ground); 5-layer compound framing with diagonal gold-and-white striped bands; serlevha on p012; gold durak (verse-separator) roundels throughout Quranic text.
paper.paper_type: Uniform buff/cream paper throughout (margins and text panels); zerefşân overlay on outer margin zones. No mülevven detected.

ruling.system: 5-layer compound altın cedvel (multi-ruled framing system) throughout all calligraphic pages.
ruling.description: The framing system from outer margin to text panel is as follows: (1) outermost gold rule line bordering the entire page; (2) buff/cream outer margin zone with zerefşân, substantial width; (3) DISTINCTIVE FEATURE — wide diagonal gold-and-white striped border band: alternating gold and white diagonal lines running at approximately 45 degrees, producing a bold geometric band visible across the full width of the frame; (4) sage-green ruled band (narrow); (5) salmon/peach ruled band (narrow); (6) fine red ruled line immediately bordering the text panel; (7) cream text field. This is a significantly more architecturally complex framing system than SM 00006 (2–3 layers) or SM 00009. The diagonal striped border bands are the single most distinctive decorative feature of the album and have not been documented in other SM albums in this corpus. They are confirmed on pp003, 007, and 012.

binding.cover_description: Dark brown/maroon lacquer-finish leather binding with a very large central gold şemse medallion — the largest binding medallion observed in the SM corpus. The şemse is nearly circular with a densely filled interior of rūmī arabesques and interlacing scrollwork. Two substantial salbek (pendant) extensions project from the horizontal axis of the şemse, each containing a subsidiary lobed cartouche in gold. Gold border tooling visible around the cover perimeter. Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi circular label (numeral '13') and a rectangular red-bordered label visible on the front cover. Türkiye Yazma Eserler Kurumu embossed stamp also present. The binding is heavier and larger in scale than the SM 00006 binding.
binding.cover_type: Ruganî/lake cilt — lacquer-finish leather binding with monumental gold şemse + salbek configuration
binding.notes: The very large şemse with elaborate salbek extensions is among the most imposing binding decorations in the SM corpus. The visual-confirmation session classified the binding as 'ornate lacquer binding with dark burgundy/maroon leather' at confidence 0.95. The scale of the şemse relative to the cover dimensions (filling nearly half the cover surface) suggests a high-prestige production context. Physical examination is needed to confirm whether this is true ruganî (lacquer) or heavily gilded leather tooling.

codicology.format: Murakkaʿ — bound Ottoman Quranic calligraphic album; 11 yaprak (folios); zerefşân + compound diagonal framing + serlevha + lacquer binding
codicology.condition_summary: Interior pages appear in good condition based on IIIF images: zerefşân margins are legible, compound framing is intact, and the serlevha on p012 is well-preserved. Binding cover (p001) shows wear. Some staining or aging visible on outer margin zones (dark speckling that may be oxidized silver sprinkling). No major losses or water damage visible in examined pages.

provenance.donor: Fethizâde Mustafa Efendi (الحاج سيد مصطفى فتحي زاده)
provenance.waqf: Vakf-ı Sâhibü'l-Hayrât el-Hâcc Seyyid Mustafa Fethizâde der-Kitâbhâne-i Câmi-i Sultan Süleyman, 1202 AH / 1787–88 CE. The album was endowed to the library of the Sultan Süleyman Mosque (Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi), Istanbul, by the charitable donor Hâcı Seyyid Mustafa Fethizâde in AH 1202. This vakf seal is shared by all SM albums in the Süleymaniye Murakka Koleksiyonu, establishing AH 1202 / 1787–88 CE as a common terminus ante quem for the entire collection.
provenance.notes: All albums in the Süleymaniye Murakka Koleksiyonu bear the Fethizâde Mustafa Efendi vakf seal dated AH 1202. This single-donor, single-date endowment suggests the albums were assembled or collected as a group before being donated together. The pre-vakf provenance of SM 00013 — particularly relevant given the possible early (15th–16th century) production date suggested by the Şeyh Hamdullah attribution — is unknown.
